lines.text: Have you a valediction, boyo?

[gasping out a name]
... Rollo Tamasi.
[last lines]
Some men get the world. Others get ex-hookers and a trip to Arizona.
[She kisses Exley on the cheek]
Bye.
Bye.
I see Bud because I want to. I see Bud because he can't hide the good inside of him. I see Bud because he treats me like Lynn Bracken and not some Veronica Lake look-alike who fucks for money.
I wouldn't trade places with Edmund Exley right now for all the whiskey in Ireland.
Edmund, you're a political animal. You have the eye for human weakness, but not the stomach.
You're wrong, sir.
Would you be willing to plant corroborative evidence on a suspect you knew to be guilty, in order to ensure an indictment?
Dudley, we've been over this.
Yes or no, Edmund?
No!
Would you be willing to beat a confession out of a suspect you knew to be guilty?
No.
Would you be willing to shoot a hardened criminal in the back, in order to offset the chance that some... lawyer...
No.
Then, for the love of God, don't be a detective. Stick to assignments where you don't have...
Dudley, I know you mean well, but I don't need to do it the way you did. Or my father.
Go back to Jersey, sonny. This is the City of the Angels, and you haven't got any wings.
I'm the technical advisor. I teach Brett Chase how to walk and talk like a cop.
Brett Chase doesn't walk and talk like you.
Well, that's 'cause he's the television version. America isn't ready for the real me.
You say "fuck" a lot.
You fuck for money.
You'll do as I say, and ask no questions. Do you follow my drift?
In technicolor, sir.
Do you make the three Negroes for the Nite Owl killings?

[puzzled]
What?
It's a simple question.
Why in the world do you wanna go digging any deeper into the Nite Owl killings... Lieutenant?
...Rollo Tamasi.
Is there more to that, or am I supposed to guess?

[aftre gathering his thoughts]
Rollo was a purse snatcher. My father ran into him off duty, and he shot my father six times and got away clean. No one even knew who he was. I just made the name up to give him some personality.
What's your point?

Rollo Tamasi is the reason I became a cop. I wanted to catch the guys who thought they could get away with it. It's supposed to be about justice. Then somewhere along the way, I lost sight of that... Why'd you become a cop?

[long pause]
I don't remember.
[brief hesitation]
What do you want, Exley?
I just wanna solve this thing.
The Nite Owl *was* solved.
No; I wanna do it right.
Even if it means paying the consequences?
[Exley nods his head, Vincennes stands up from his chair]

All right, college boy, I'll help. But there's a case you boys in Homicide don't care about, you think it's just another Hollywood "homo"-cide. Well, I don't. You help me with mine, I'll help you with yours. Deal?
Deal.
The Nite Owl case made you. Do you want to tear all that down?
With a wrecking ball... You want to help me swing it?
I'd like to see you again.
Are you asking me for a date, or an appointment?
...I don't know.
Well, if you're asking me for a date, I should know your first name.

[embarrassed]
Forget I asked. It was a mistake.
You're the first man in five years who didn't tell me I look like Veronica Lake inside of a minute.
You look better than Veronica Lake.
Merry Christmas.
Merry Christmas to you, officer.
That obvious, huh?
It's practically stamped on your forehead.

[told by Bud to leave Lynn's house]
Maybe I will. Maybe I won't.

[flashes his badge]
LAPD, shitbird. Get the fuck outta here or I'll call your wife to come get you!
[while Lynn hides a smile, the client gathers up his clothes, and walks out front door]
Officer.
Councilman.
You want an autograph? Write to MGM.
Since when do two-bit hoods and hookers give out autographs?
What'd you say to me?
LAPD. Sit down.
Who in the hell do you think you are?
Ed...
Take a walk, honey, before I haul your ass downtown.
You are making a large mistake.
Get away from our table!
Shut up! A hooker cut to look like Lana Turner is still a hooker.
Hey!
She just looks like Lana Turner.
She *is* Lana Turner.

[stunned]
What?
She *is* Lana Turner.
[Lana throws a drink in Ed's face]
A naked man with a gun? Do you really expect anyone to believe that?
Get the fuck away from me.
How's it gonna look in your report?
It'll look like justice. That's what the man got. Justice.
You don't know the meaning of the word, you ignorant bastard.
Oh yeah, well you think it means getting your picture in the paper. Why don't you go after criminals for a change, instead of cops?
[punches Exley in the shoulder and then starts to walk away]
Stensland got what he deserved, and so will you.
[a furious White tries to attack Exley, only to be restrained by the Captain and by several other cops]
It's best to stay away from a man when his blood is up.
His blood is always up.
Then perhaps you should stay away from him altogether.
All I ever wanted was to measure up to my father.
Now's your chance.

[after Exley gives him a puzzled look]
He died in the line of duty, didn't he?
Bud White is a valuable officer.
White's a mindless thug.
No, Edmund, he's just a man who can answer yes to those questions I've asked you from time to time.
Are you tight with the DA, Jackie?
Oh yeah, yeah, yeah. He tried to throw me off the force last Christmas as a little joke.
Something's wrong with the Nite Owl. I know it in here,
[points to his chest]

I know it. That prick Exley shot the wrong guys. Whoever killed my partner, is still out there. I... If I could work cases like a real detective, I could prove it. But I'm not smart enough. I'm just the guy they bring in to scare the other guy shitless.
You're wrong. You found Patchett, you found me. You're smart enough.
Off the record, on the QT, and very hush-hush.
[White approaches Loew in the bathroom, after he refused to answer Exley's questions]
Unless you came in here to wipe my ass, I believe we're through.
[White looks at him, silently]
Come on, don't try this "Good Cop-Bad Cop" crap on me. I practically invented it. So what if some homo actor is dead? Boys, girls, ten of them step off the bus to L.A. every day.
[White proceeds to smash Loew's head into the mirror and then sticking it into the toilet]
Pull him off me, Exley!
I don't know how.
if I take you out, there'll be ten more lawyers to take your place tomorrow. They just won't come on the bus, that's all!
[White drags Loew into his office and dangles him out of the window by his legs until he confesses]
Was that how you used to run the "Good Cop-Bad Cop?"
[White catches a parolee beating his wife]
Who in the hell are you?
The ghost of Christmas past. Why don't you dance with a man for a change?
What are you, some kind of smart ass?
[tries to attack Bud]

[after beating up and handcuffing the wife beater]
You'll be out in a year and a half. I'll get cozy with your parole officer. You touch her again, I'll have you violated on a kiddie raper beef.

[grabs wife beater by the head]
You know what they do to kiddie rapers in Quentin, don't ya?

[to Ed]
Fucking me and fucking Bud aren't the same thing, you know.

[Captain Smith briefs the squad room on Jack Vincennes' death; Exley is standing beside him]
Sergeant Vincennes was killed by a .32 slug to the heart. Time of death, approximately 1 a.m. Although he was found in Echo Park, preliminary forensics indicates his body was most likely moved. I want two-man teams to scour that entire neighborhood. Our justice must be swift and merciless. That is all.

[Exley starts to leave with the other officers]
Edmund, might I have a word with you? We're trying to run down a lead on an associate of Vincennes. The records check has led to a dead end.
What's the name?
Rollo Tomasi. Have you ever heard Vincennes mention him?

[poker-faced]
No. No, I haven't.
Well, it's probably nothing. Still, keep your eyes open, eh, boyo?
[Captain Smith exits as Exley glares at him from behind]
I admire you as a policeman - particularly your adherence to violence as a necessary adjunct to the job.
Oh, great. You get the girl, I get the coroner.
I use girls that look like movie stars. Sometimes I employ a plastic surgeon. When the work had been done, that's when you saw us.
That's why her mother couldn't I.D. her. Jesus fucking Christ.
No, Mr. White. Pierce Morehouse Patchett.
Don't start tryin' to do the right thing, boy-o. You haven't the practice.

'It's Christmas Eve in the City of Angels and while decent citizens sleep the sleep of the righteous, hopheads prowl for marijuana, not knowing that a man is coming to stop them! Celebrity crimestopper Jack Vincennes, scourge of grasshoppers and dopefiends everywhere!' Ya like it, Jackie boy?
Yeah, subtle.
Bullshit. How would a two-bit hick like Meeks get his hands on a large supply of heroin?
You're right, it's probably bullshit. Even if he did, he could never unload it. Not without drawing all kinds of attention.
Maybe that's why he's under a house in Elysian Park and he don't smell too good, paisano.
You're like Santa Claus with that list, Bud, except everyone on it's been naughty.
[lying in bed, Lynn touches a scar on Bud's shoulder]
Where'd this come from?
When I was twelve, my old man went after my mother with a bottle. I got in the way.
You saved her.
...Not for long.
I'm sorry, Bud, it's none of my...
He tied me to the radiator. I watched him beat my mother to death with a tire iron. Then he left us there. Three days before a truant officer found us... They never found the old man.
Was that why you became a cop? To get even?
...Maybe.
the great jerkoff case of 1953.
I got a hot date.
Yeah? Who is she and what did you arrest her for?
[first lines]

[voiceover]
Come to Los Angeles! The sun shines bright, the beaches are wide and inviting, and the orange groves stretch as far as the eye can see. There are jobs aplenty, and land is cheap. Every working man can have his own house, and inside every house, a happy, all-American family. You can have all this, and who knows... you could even be discovered, become a movie star... or at least see one. Life is good in Los Angeles... it's paradise on Earth." Ha ha ha ha. That's what they tell you, anyway.
[Bud grabs Johnny Stompanato by the testicles to get him to talk]
What do I get if I give you your balls back, you wop cocksucker?
[Exley has to perform the interrogation]
Are you sure Golden Boy is up to the task, Cap?
Oh, I think you'd be surprised what the lad is capable of.
Hold up your badge, so they'll know you're a policeman.
Karen, this is Sid Hudgens of Hush-Hush Magazine.
Hellooooo, Karen!
Hello yourself!
[walks off angrily]
What's that about?
Eh, we ran a piece last year, "Ingenue Dykes in Hollywood." Her name got mentioned.
[to Ray Collins]
They called you 'Sugar', 'cause you liked to give it out... so sweet.
Bud hates himself for what he did.
I know how he feels.
How's it hanging, Sid?
Down around my ankles.
There's blood on your jacket. Is that an integral part of your job?
Sometimes.
Do you enjoy it?
When they deserve it.
Did they today?
I don't know.
But you did it anyway.
Yeah, just like the half-dozen guys you screwed today.
Well, actually, it was two.
I was wondering when you'd knock on my door again, Officer White.
It's Bud.
Bud...
We'll do the town one night... on me.
I'll bring my wallet, just in case.
Excuse me, ma'am; just the facts.
I'm talking about the gas chamber, and you haven't even asked me what this is about. You've got a big "Guilty" sign around your neck.
Why don't you and I go someplace quiet, cause I'd love to give you the low-down on Mitchum.
[Dick Stensland arrives with liquor for a party]
What took you, Stensland?
My partner stopped to help a damsel in distress. He's got his priorities all screwed up.
I doubt you've ever taken a stupid breath. Don't start now.
Get me some narco skinny. I want to do an all-hophead issue. You know, schwartze jazz musicians and movie stars. You like it?
Stomach of the week. Unemployed actor had frankfurter, french fries, alcohol, and sperm. Hell of a last supper, don't you think?
[when Sid Hudgens is found dead]
What happened?
Somebody beat him to death and stole a bunch of files. Must've dug up garbage on the wrong guy. Got it narrowed down to a thousand suspects.
[to Lynn]
Don't ever try to fucking bribe me or I'll have you and Patchett in shit up to your ears.

[interrogation at the Victory Motel]
Reciprocity, Mr. Hudgens, is the key to every relationship.

[as Bud White is beating him up]
Think, goddamn you, *think!*
[Before killing Sid Hudgens]
Hush hush.
I'll need another fifty dollars. That's two twenties for the two arresting officers and a dime for the watch commander.
[Stocking a box with liquor for the police's Christmas party]
If I ever get held up, you guys better be here.
Wendell - I'd like full and docile co-operation on every topic.
Well, Captain, what do you want?
Call me Dudley.
Dudley... what do you want?
I heard you like to shoot dogs.
Dogs got no reason to live.
Our justice must be swift and merciless.

[voiceover]
Something has to be done, but nothing too original, because hey, this is Hollywood.
You're a bit of a puzzlement to me these days, Wendell. You don't seem to be your old cruel self anymore. And I had such grand plans for your future.
He's on a night train to the big adios.
Bud White - what brings *you* to the basement?
I got a couple Nite Owl questions.
I don't know if you'd read the papers, but that case is closed.
Is there anything bothering you about it, Ray?
Yeah, the fact that the pack-up boys haven't carted this shit out of here yet.
[Bud sees all the boxes of case files, and starts to look through the crime scene photos]
I got three shotguns, taken from the suspects, that match the strike marks on the shells from the Nite Owl. What more do you want?

[suddenly spotting a detail in a photo]
There's blood on the wall here. I thought everybody but the cook got shot in the men's room?
That is Stensland's blood.
Stensland?
He took a blow to the head. Was probably unconscious when they dragged him in the john.
Did they hit anybody else?
No. But he was a cop, he probably tried to "do something."

[remembering that Stensland said he had a date that night, he studies a photo showing a table with two settings, including a coffee mug smudged with lipstick]
Grilled cheese, black coffee... two of the victims were women, right?
Yeah - Patti DeLuca, the night-shift waitress, and a Susan Lefferts.
Susan Lefferts...
Yeah, what about her?
[Bud runs out of the room]
You're welcome!
